items.title: Several killed as Iran protests over economy turn deadly

featured_image.name: Iran's protests led by shopkeepers is shaking up the regime

items.description:
Violent clashes between protesters and security forces left several people dead across Iran on January 1, marking the most deadly escalation yet in demonstrations that erupted four days earlier over soaring inflation and a collapsing currency[1][2][3][4]. The unrest represents the largest wave of protests in Iran since 2022, when the death of Mahsa Amini sparked nationwide demonstrations[1][2][3].

Semi-official media and rights groups reported multiple fatalities in at least three provinces. Fars news agency said two people were killed in Lordegan, a city in western Iran, during clashes between security services and protesters[5][6][7]. The human rights organization Hengaw corroborated deaths in Lordegan, saying security forces opened fire on demonstrators[8][5][9]. Another death was reported in Isfahan province in central Iran[5][6][7].

Authorities confirmed one person killed in Kuhdasht, a western city, though accounts of the incident diverged sharply. State media identified the deceased as Amirhossam Khodayari Fard, a 21-year-old member of the Basij paramilitary unit[2][5][10][7]. The Revolutionary Guards said 13 other militia members were wounded and accused demonstrators of "taking advantage of the atmosphere of popular protests"[7][5]. However, Hengaw said Khodayari Fard was a protester killed by security forces[5][6][7]. Reuters could not independently verify the reports[7][4].

items.title: Interstellar object traced to Milky Way core; no alien signals detected

featured_image.name: Rare Interstellar Object 3I/ATLAS Fails Alien Test, Scientists Say

items.description:
The interstellar visitor 3I/ATLAS has been traced to the violent heart of the Milky Way, while the most sensitive radio search ever conducted on such an object found no evidence of artificial technology, scientists reported in late December 2025.

Discovered on July 1, 2025, by the Asteroid Terrestrial-impact Last Alert System in Chile, 3I/ATLAS is only the third confirmed object from another star system to enter our solar neighborhood[1][2][3][4]. Recent observations have pinpointed its origin to the direction of Sagittarius, a corridor leading to the galaxy's turbulent core roughly 26,000 light-years away[2][3][5].

"It has been approaching from the general direction of the constellation Sagittarius, which is where the central region of our galaxy, the Milky Way, is located," NASA confirmed[5]. The object's trajectory and hyperbolic excess velocity of approximately 58 kilometers per second suggest it was ejected from a high-energy environment marked by intense radiation and dense stellar traffic[1][2][3].

items.title: Fire kills dozens at Swiss ski resort bar during New Year's

featured_image.name: Fire tears through bar at Swiss Alps ski resort Crans-Montana during New Year's celebrations

items.description:
A devastating fire tore through a packed bar in the Swiss Alps early Thursday morning, killing several dozen people and injuring around 100 others as revelers celebrated the arrival of 2026. The blaze at Le Constellation bar in Crans-Montana erupted around 1:30 AM local time, transforming a festive New Year's gathering into what authorities described as one of Switzerland's worst tragedies[1][2][3][4][5][6][7].

"Several tens of people" were presumed dead, Valais Canton police commander Frédéric Gisler said during a news conference Thursday morning, though he emphasized it was premature to provide a precise figure as work continues to identify victims and notify families[1][3][6][7]. The Italian foreign ministry, citing Swiss police, estimated around 40 fatalities[4][8][9]. More than 100 people were inside the bar when the fire broke out, witnesses and officials said[2][5][6].

items.title: Satellites to enable seamless global 5G and 6G by 2030

featured_image.name: AST SpaceMobile Launches Its Most Powerful Direct-to-Cell ...

items.description:
Satellite communication systems are poised to integrate with terrestrial mobile networks by 2030, eliminating dead zones and delivering the next generation of wireless connectivity to billions of smartphones worldwide, according to a comprehensive analysis published this week in the journal Engineering.

The article, "Evolution of Satellite Communication Systems Toward 5G/6G for 2030 and Beyond," reviews how satellites at various orbital altitudes will combine with ground-based infrastructure to form a unified 5G and 6G communications platform[1][2][3]. The International Telecommunication Union has designated 2030 as the target for deploying IMT-2030—the official designation for 6G—which aims to deliver peak speeds of 1 terabit per second, a hundredfold increase over current 5G networks[4][5].

items.title: US says Ukraine did not target Putin in drone strike

featured_image.name: RUSSIA-UKRAINE-CONFLICT

items.description:
U.S. national security officials determined that Ukraine did not target Russian President Vladimir Putin or his residences in a recent drone strike, contradicting Moscow's allegations and casting doubt on claims that threaten to derail peace negotiations.

The assessment, backed by the Central Intelligence Agency, found no evidence Ukraine aimed at Putin in the alleged December 28-29 incident, according to a U.S. official familiar with the intelligence[1][2][3]. The finding was first reported by The Wall Street Journal on Wednesday[4][5].

Russia claimed on Monday that Ukraine launched 91 long-range attack drones at Putin's Valdai residence in the Novgorod region, calling it a "terrorist attack"[6][7][8]. Russian Foreign Minister Sergey Lavrov said all drones were intercepted and warned Moscow would revise its negotiating position[7][9][8]. However, Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy swiftly dismissed the allegations as "another lie" intended to sabotage diplomatic progress[9][10].

items.title: NASA to launch Artemis II moon mission in 2026

featured_image.name: 2026 set to be the year NASA astronauts fly around the moon ...

items.description:
NASA is preparing to return astronauts to the moon's vicinity for the first time in more than half a century, while stargazers can look forward to a spectacular total lunar eclipse and the year's brightest supermoon.

The Artemis II mission is scheduled to launch no earlier than February 5, 2026, with launch windows open through the end of April, according to NASA officials[1][2][3]. The 10-day mission will send four astronauts—NASA's Reid Wiseman, Victor Glover and Christina Koch, along with Canadian Space Agency astronaut Jeremy Hansen—on a lunar flyby[4][5]. The crew will become the first people to travel beyond low-Earth orbit since Apollo 17 in December 1972[1][4]. Glover will be the first Black man, Koch the first woman, and Hansen the first non-American to venture this far from Earth[6].

items.title: U.S. grants TSMC annual license for chip gear exports to China

featured_image.name: US revokes TSMC Nanjing VEU by 2025,…

items.description: The US Department of Commerce has issued an annual export license to Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing, allowing the chipmaker to continue importing American manufacturing equipment to its facility in Nanjing, China, the company announced Thursday[1][2]. The approval, granted just before a longstanding waiver system expired on December 31, marks a shift from blanket permissions to tighter, year-by-year controls[1][2].

items.title: US, Ukraine, European allies hold peace talks

featured_image.name: US held talks with Ukraine, European countries on next steps in ending Ukraine war, Witkoff says

items.description:
President Donald Trump's advisors held telephone discussions on December 31 with Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskiy and national security advisors from the United Kingdom, France, and Germany to strategize on next steps in ending Russia's war in Ukraine, according to U.S. special envoy Steve Witkoff[1][2][3].

The talks, which included U.S. Secretary of State Marco Rubio, Trump's son-in-law Jared Kushner, and Ukraine's chief negotiator Rustem Umerov, focused on strengthening security guarantees, developing deconfliction mechanisms, and advancing a "prosperity package" for Ukraine's post-war recovery[1][2][4]. French President Emmanuel Macron announced that many European states and allies will make concrete commitments to protect Ukraine at a meeting in Paris on January 6[5][5].

"We focused on how to move the discussions forward in a practical way on behalf of @POTUS' peace process, including strengthening security guarantees and developing effective deconfliction mechanisms to help end the war and ensure it does not restart," Witkoff wrote on social media[2][4].

items.title: Trump shares editorial blasting Putin as Ukraine talks stall

featured_image.name: Trump Shares Editorial Criticizing Putin After Talks Stall ...

items.description:
President Donald Trump on Wednesday signaled frustration with Russian President Vladimir Putin by sharing a New York Post editorial that blames the Kremlin for obstructing peace negotiations in Ukraine[1][2]. The editorial, titled "Putin 'attack' bluster shows Russia is the one standing in the way of peace," was posted to Trump's Truth Social account without additional comment[3][2].

The public rebuke came hours before Putin delivered his annual New Year's address vowing victory in Ukraine, telling troops "we believe in you and our victory"[4][5]. The dueling messages highlighted the difficulties facing U.S.-led efforts to broker an end to the nearly four-year conflict, despite Trump's recent optimism that a deal may be within reach.

items.title: China installs world's most powerful hypergravity centrifuge

featured_image.name: China's record 1900g-tonne hypergravity machine compresses ...

items.description:
China has taken the lead in hypergravity research with the arrival of CHIEF1900, a centrifuge capable of generating gravitational forces 1,900 times stronger than Earth's gravity. Developed by Shanghai Electric Nuclear Power Group, the machine was delivered to Zhejiang University on December 22 and is currently being installed at the university's underground research facility in Hangzhou[1][2].

Once operational, CHIEF1900 will surpass all existing hypergravity centrifuges worldwide, including its predecessor CHIEF1300, which began operations in September with a capacity of 1,300 gravity-tonnes[1][3]. The previous world record was held by the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers facility in Vicksburg, Mississippi, with a capacity of approximately 1,200 gravity-tonnes[1][4].

items.title: Search for Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 resumes in Indian Ocean

featured_image.name: HUGIN AUV to Ocean Infinity - Kongsberg Maritime

items.description:
A search vessel equipped with advanced underwater robots arrived in the Indian Ocean on Wednesday to resume the hunt for Malaysia Airlines Flight 370, marking the first major effort in years to solve one of aviation's most enduring mysteries[1][2][3].

Malaysia's Transport Ministry confirmed that the Armada 86 05 reached a designated search area with two autonomous underwater vehicles, reviving hopes of finally locating the Boeing 777 that vanished with 239 people on board on March 8, 2014[1][2][4]. The ministry did not disclose the exact location of the search zone, but stated the vessel prepared for operations at Fremantle Port in Western Australia[1][2].

items.title: Nvidia in talks to acquire AI21 Labs for up to $3B

featured_image.name: In this photo illustration, a NVIDIA logo is seen displayed...

items.description:
Nvidia is positioning itself to capitalize on surging AI demand through two major transactions announced this week: a planned $14 billion chip purchase from ByteDance and the potential acquisition of Israeli AI startup AI21 Labs for up to $3 billion.

The dual deals underscore the chipmaker's aggressive expansion strategy as competition intensifies in artificial intelligence infrastructure, though both transactions face regulatory hurdles that could determine their ultimate success.

items.title: Big Four firms deploy thousands of AI agents in 2025

featured_image.name: Big Four bet on AI agents that can do all the work and 'liberate' staff

items.description:
As 2025 draws to a close, artificial intelligence has fundamentally reshaped professional services and management roles, with the workforce racing to adapt through intensive reskilling as organizations prepare for even deeper transformation in 2026.

The Big Four professional services firms—Deloitte, EY, PwC, and KPMG—have deployed thousands of AI agents this year, setting a blueprint for how businesses worldwide will operate[1][2][3]. EY advanced 1,000 AI agents into development or production in 2025, with plans to scale to 100,000 by 2028[3][4]. PwC deployed 25,000 intelligent agents across client operations[4], while Deloitte's Zora AI platform reduced finance team costs by 25% and increased productivity by 40%[5][6].

items.title: Harvard scientist defends alien probe theory despite new images

featured_image.name: Interstellar comet 3I/ATLAS caught on camera in new ... - Space

items.description:
As interstellar visitor 3I/ATLAS speeds away from the inner solar system, Harvard astrophysicist Avi Loeb continues to argue the object exhibits too many anomalies to dismiss extraterrestrial origins, even as new telescope images debunk viral theories that it was deliberately hiding itself.

Fresh observations from the Hubble Space Telescope captured on December 12 and 27 reveal a stable double-jet structure streaming from the comet's nucleus, while separate imaging shows the object's outer coma is thinning naturally rather than through any intentional cloaking mechanism, according to International Business Times UK[1][2]. The object made its closest approach to Earth on December 19 at approximately 168 million miles, offering astronomers a final window to study the third confirmed interstellar visitor to our solar system[3][2].

items.title: Gold and silver post strongest gains since 1979

featured_image.name: Gold, silver head for biggest annual gains in over 40 years

items.description:
Gold and silver are poised to end 2025 with their most impressive annual gains in more than four decades, despite sharp late-December selloffs that underscored the extraordinary volatility in precious metals markets.

Gold climbed approximately 66% this year, while silver surged over 150%, according to multiple market sources[1][2][3][4]. Both metals are heading for their strongest yearly performance since 1979, when the Iranian Revolution and runaway inflation drove gold up 126%[1][5][6][7].

The year-end rally turned turbulent in late December when CME Group raised margin requirements on precious metals futures twice within a week[8][9][10]. The exchange cited "market volatility to ensure adequate collateral coverage" as silver broke above $80 per ounce for the first time and gold approached $4,550[8][11]. Silver margins jumped approximately 30%, while gold requirements rose roughly 9%, forcing traders to post additional cash during one of the year's thinnest trading periods[12][10].

Silver plunged nearly 9% on Monday, December 29, to just above $73 per ounce after briefly exceeding $84 over the weekend[13]. Gold dropped more than 4% to around $4,355[13]. Both metals staged recoveries on Tuesday before falling again Wednesday, with silver declining more than 8% and gold slipping approximately 0.75%[13][14].

items.title: Xi declares Taiwan reunification 'unstoppable'

featured_image.name: Xi reaffirms China's claim to Taiwan in New Year's address - Yahoo

items.description:
Chinese President Xi Jinping declared Wednesday that Taiwan's reunification with China is "unstoppable," capping off 2025 with a forceful message about the self-ruled island's future. In his annual New Year's Eve address, Xi said Chinese people on both sides of the Taiwan Strait share "a bond of blood and kinship," adding that "the reunification of our motherland, a trend of the times, is unstoppable"[1][2][3].

The remarks came one day after China's People's Liberation Army announced it had "successfully completed" Justice Mission 2025, a two-day military exercise that encircled Taiwan with warships, fighter jets, and missile forces[1][2][4]. Senior Captain Li Xi, spokesperson for the PLA's Eastern Theater Command, said the drills "fully tested the integrated joint operations capabilities" of Chinese troops[1][4].

items.title: Russia, Ukraine exchange strikes on power grids

featured_image.name: Why is Russia escalating attacks on Ukraine’s Odesa?

items.description:
Russian drone attacks on Ukraine's southern port city of Odesa left six people injured and more than 170,000 residents without electricity overnight December 30-31, while a major power outage struck Moscow's suburbs affecting over 100,000 people during the same period, according to local authorities and energy officials.

The Russian assault on Odesa damaged four apartment buildings and struck two energy facilities operated by DTEK, Ukraine's largest private power company, leaving parts of the city without electricity, water, and heating amid freezing temperatures[1][2][3][4]. Among the wounded were three children—ages seven months, eight, and 14—while a 42-year-old man remained in serious condition[5][2][6]. Firefighters rescued eight people from burning buildings as flames engulfed residential structures[4][7].

"Another proof that Russia is targeting civilians," Serhii Lysak, head of Odesa City Military Administration, wrote on social media[7]. The Ukrainian Energy Ministry reported that emergency repair work was underway, though restoration efforts have been hampered by the extent of damage to critical infrastructure[8][9][10].

items.title: Finland seizes cargo ship after undersea cables damaged

featured_image.name: Finland detains vessel after cables damaged between Tallinn ...

items.description:
Finnish authorities seized a cargo vessel on Wednesday after two telecommunications cables connecting Helsinki and Tallinn were damaged in the Gulf of Finland, marking the latest incident in a series of suspected sabotage attacks on critical Baltic Sea infrastructure.

The Finnish Border Guard intercepted the cargo ship Fitburg after telecoms provider Elisa detected a fault in one of its submarine cables early Wednesday morning[1][2]. The vessel, which departed Saint Petersburg on December 30 and was en route to Israel, was found operating with its anchor chain deployed in Finland's exclusive economic zone[1][2]. The actual damage to the cables occurred in Estonia's economic zone[1][3][2].

"Finland is prepared for a range of security challenges and will respond as required," President Alexander Stubb said in a statement on social media[1]. Prime Minister Petteri Orpo confirmed that state agencies are working together to determine the cause and extent of the damage[1].

The Fitburg, flying the flag of Saint Vincent and the Grenadines, was ordered to raise its anchor and proceed to Finnish territorial waters where it remains under state control[1]. Helsinki Police Department is investigating the incident as aggravated criminal damage, attempted aggravated criminal damage, and aggravated interference with telecommunications[1][3][2]. The inquiry is being conducted in cooperation with Finnish Defence Forces, Customs, and Estonian authorities[1].

items.title: Iran replaces central bank chief as protests spread nationwide

featured_image.name: Protests in Iran spread amid deep discontent over economic duress

items.description:
Demonstrations erupted across Iran for the fourth consecutive day on Tuesday as the national currency collapsed to historic lows, prompting President Masoud Pezeshkian to replace his central bank governor and pledge government action to address mounting economic grievances[1][2][3].

The protests began Sunday when merchants in Tehran's Grand Bazaar shuttered their shops after the rial plunged to approximately 1.42 million against the U.S. dollar, compared to 820,000 a year earlier[1][2]. By Monday, strikes had spread beyond the capital to Isfahan, Shiraz, Kermanshah, Yazd, Zanjan, and Hamadan, with security forces deploying tear gas and, according to unverified reports, live ammunition to disperse crowds[4][5][6].

University students joined the demonstrations Tuesday, with protests reported at more than ten campuses nationwide[1][3][7]. Videos circulating on social media showed students chanting "Death to the dictator," referring to Supreme Leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, while others tore down signs representing his office at Beheshti University[2][7][8]. The Guild Council of the University of Tehran said six students were detained but later released[4].

items.title: Global stocks surge as emerging markets outpace US

featured_image.name: From the US to China, 2025 a blockbuster year for stock markets

items.description:
Stock markets worldwide capped 2025 with robust gains, as emerging markets outpaced developed peers for the first time in five years and artificial intelligence infrastructure spending drove a shift in technology sector leadership beyond the usual giants.

The MSCI All Country World Index, tracking over 2,500 stocks across developed and emerging markets, rose more than 21% through late December to reach record highs[1][2]. Even more striking, the MSCI ACWI Ex-US index achieved its best performance since the 2009 global financial crisis, climbing approximately 30% as investors diversified away from concentrated U.S. positions[3][4]. By comparison, the S&P 500 gained 18.7% for the year, marking its third consecutive annual advance[5][6].

South Korea's KOSPI index led all major global markets with a stunning 75.6% gain, its strongest annual performance since 1999[7][8]. The rally was powered by semiconductor manufacturers SK Hynix and Samsung Electronics, whose shares surged approximately 280% and 125% respectively on surging demand for high-bandwidth memory chips used in AI systems[7][9].

Latin America emerged as an unexpected star, with Colombia's equity market skyrocketing over 91% to claim the top spot globally, according to data compiled by Morningstar for CNBC[1]. Chile, Peru, Mexico, and Brazil all posted gains exceeding 45%, establishing the region as a standout performer[1]. Analysts attributed Colombia's rally to low initial valuations, improving investor sentiment ahead of presidential elections, and a Colombian peso that appreciated nearly 15% against the dollar[1].
